Top-3 Scripts:
so_62651044: find . -maxdepth 1 -type f -name '[0-9]*' -not -name '1_*' -delete

find . -maxdepth 1 -type f -name '[0-9]*' -not -name '1_*' -exec rm {} +

Explanations about Options.-not: Same as ! expr, but not POSIX compliant.
Explanations about Options.-name:
This option is supported, but POSIX conformance depends on the POSIX conformance of
 the system's fnmatch(3) library function. As of findutils-4.2.2, shell
 metacharacters (`*', `?' or `[]' for example) will match a leading `.', because
 IEEE PASC interpretation 126 requires this. This is a change from previous
 versions of findutils.
Explanations about Options.-maxdepth:
Descend at most levels (a non-negative integer) levels of directories below the
 starting-points. -maxdepth 0 means only apply the tests and actions to the
 starting-points themselves.

Answers.Most Similar TLDR Task: Recursively remove a directory and all its subdirectories
Top-3 Similar Questions: su_168130: Unix - delete files and folders excluding PATTERN
so_62651044: Deleting files not containing double digit number and pattern in grep
Top-3 Scripts:
su_168130: rm -rf

rm -ri

# ksh
echo rm -rf !(*foo*)

# bash
shopt -s extglob
echo rm -rf !(*foo*)

# zsh
setopt extended_glob
echo rm -rf ^*foo*

# zsh: ksh-style glob syntax
setopt ksh_glob no_bare_glob_qual
echo rm -rf !(*foo*)

# zsh: ksh-style glob syntax, adapted for the default bare_glob_qual option
setopt ksh_glob bare_glob_qual
echo rm -rf (!(*foo*))

Explanations about Options.-r: remove directories and their contents recursively
Explanations about Options.-f: ignore nonexistent files and arguments, never prompt

Answers.Most Similar TLDR Task: Recursively copy a directory's contents to another location (if the destination exists, the directory is copied inside it)
Top-3 Similar Questions: so_20871845: grep a keyword in all .h and .c files under current directory but exclude two directories
Top-3 Scripts:
so_20871845: mkdir a b c d
for d in a b c d
do
    for file in abc def pqr zyz
    do
        for ext in c h
        do cp /dev/null $d/$file.$ext
        done
    done
done
